title: A97-1020

sentences.text: GLOSSER is designed to support reading and learning to read in a foreign language .
There are four language pairs currently supported by GLOSSER : English-Bulgarian , English-Estonian , English-Hungarian and French-Dutch .
The program is operational on UNIX and Windows '95 platforms , and has undergone a pilot user-study .

A demonstration -LRB- in UNIX -RRB- for Applied Natural Language Processing emphasizes components put to novel technical uses in intelligent computer-assisted morphological analysis -LRB- ICALL -RRB- , including disambiguated morphological analysis and lemmatized indexing for an aligned bilingual corpus of word examples .

Entity-program.label: program
Entity-program.description: The program refers to GLOSSER, a software application designed to support reading and learning in foreign languages, operational on UNIX and Windows '95 platforms.

Entity-glosser.label: GLOSSER
Entity-glosser.description: GLOSSER is an educational software tool designed to assist users in reading and learning foreign languages, supporting multiple language pairs and utilizing advanced morphological analysis techniques.

Entity-four_language_pair.label: four language pairs
Entity-four_language_pair.description: The term 'four language pairs' refers to the specific combinations of languages supported by the GLOSSER program for reading and learning, which include English-Bulgarian, English-Estonian, English-Hungarian, and French-Dutch.

Entity-french-dutch.label: French-Dutch
Entity-french-dutch.description: French-Dutch refers to the language pair used in the GLOSSER program, which facilitates reading and learning in both French and Dutch.

Entity-reading_and_learning_to_read_in_a.label: reading and learning to read in a foreign language
aliases: reading and learning to read in a foreign language
Entity-reading_and_learning_to_read_in_a.description: Reading and learning to read in a foreign language refers to the process and activities involved in acquiring literacy skills in a language that is not one's native language, facilitated by tools such as GLOSSER, which supports various language pairs and employs advanced computational techniques.

mentions.local_name: reading and learning to read in a foreign language

Entity-demonstration.label: demonstration
Entity-demonstration.description: The demonstration refers to a presentation conducted in a UNIX environment showcasing the capabilities of the GLOSSER program in Applied Natural Language Processing, particularly its innovative applications in intelligent computer-assisted morphological analysis.

Entity-reading.label: reading
Entity-reading.description: Reading refers to the cognitive process and skill of interpreting written language, which GLOSSER aims to support in the context of learning foreign languages.

Entity-word_example.label: word examples
Entity-word_example.description: The term 'word examples' refers to a collection of words used in the context of an aligned bilingual corpus to facilitate disambiguated morphological analysis and lemmatized indexing in the GLOSSER program for language learning.

Entity-english-bulgarian.label: English-Bulgarian
Entity-english-bulgarian.description: English-Bulgarian refers to the pair of languages consisting of English and Bulgarian, often used in translation and language learning contexts.

Entity-icall.label: ICALL
Entity-icall.description: ICALL refers to intelligent computer-assisted language learning, specifically in the context of morphological analysis techniques used in language processing systems.

Entity-english-hungarian.label: English-Hungarian
Entity-english-hungarian.description: English-Hungarian refers to the language pair consisting of the English and Hungarian languages, often used in translation and language learning contexts.

Entity-a_demonstration.label: A demonstration
Entity-a_demonstration.description: A demonstration refers to a practical showcase in UNIX for Applied Natural Language Processing that highlights innovative applications of intelligent computer-assisted morphological analysis, including disambiguated morphological analysis and lemmatized indexing for a bilingual corpus.

Entity-intelligent_computer-assisted_mor.label: intelligent computer-assisted morphological analysis
Entity-intelligent_computer-assisted_mor.description: Intelligent computer-assisted morphological analysis refers to a technique used in natural language processing that employs computer algorithms to perform morphological analysis, including disambiguation and lemmatization, to enhance language learning and reading comprehension in foreign languages.

Entity-aligned_bilingual_corpus_of_word_.label: aligned bilingual corpus of word examples
aliases: aligned bilingual corpus of word examples
Entity-aligned_bilingual_corpus_of_word_.description: An aligned bilingual corpus of word examples is a structured collection of word pairs in two languages that are matched for direct translation, used to facilitate language learning and computational linguistic analysis.

mentions.local_name: aligned bilingual corpus of word examples

Entity-disambiguated_morphological_analy.label: disambiguated morphological analysis
Entity-disambiguated_morphological_analy.description: Disambiguated morphological analysis refers to a technique used in intelligent computer-assisted language learning (ICALL) that involves resolving ambiguities in the morphological structure of words to enhance the processing and understanding of bilingual corpora.

Entity-bilingual_corpus.label: bilingual corpus
Entity-bilingual_corpus.description: A bilingual corpus is a linguistic resource that consists of texts in two languages, aligned at the sentence or phrase level, used for various applications in natural language processing and linguistic research.

Entity-aligned_bilingual_corpus.label: aligned bilingual corpus
Entity-aligned_bilingual_corpus.description: An aligned bilingual corpus is a linguistic resource that consists of pairs of texts in two languages, aligned at the sentence or phrase level, facilitating comparative analysis and translation studies.

Entity-learning_to_read.label: learning to read
Entity-learning_to_read.description: learning to read refers to the process of acquiring the ability to understand and interpret written language.

Entity-english-estonian.label: English-Estonian
Entity-english-estonian.description: English-Estonian refers to a language pair involving the English and Estonian languages, typically used in the context of translation or bilingual communication.

Entity-language_pair.label: language pairs
Entity-language_pair.description: Language pairs refer to combinations of two languages that are used together for translation, communication, or linguistic analysis.

Entity-applied_natural_language_processi.label: Applied Natural Language Processing
Entity-applied_natural_language_processi.description: Applied Natural Language Processing is an academic discipline and research area that focuses on the application of natural language processing techniques to solve real-world problems.

Entity-foreign_language.label: foreign language
Entity-foreign_language.description: A foreign language is any language that is not the native language of a person or community, often learned for communication, education, or cultural exchange.

Entity-lemmatized_indexing.label: lemmatized indexing
Entity-lemmatized_indexing.description: Lemmatized indexing is a linguistic technique that involves organizing and retrieving words based on their base or dictionary forms, known as lemmas, to enhance the efficiency and accuracy of information retrieval in natural language processing.

Entity-window_95.label: Windows '95
Entity-window_95.description: Windows '95 is a graphical operating system developed by Microsoft, released in 1995, that serves as a platform for running software applications.

Entity-unix.label: UNIX
Entity-unix.description: UNIX is a family of multitasking, multiuser computer operating systems that derive from the original AT&T Unix, known for its portability, security, and powerful command-line interface.

Entity-pilot_user-study.label: pilot user-study
Entity-pilot_user-study.description: A pilot user-study is a preliminary research evaluation conducted with a small group of users to test the feasibility, time, cost, and adverse events involved in a larger study.

summary: GLOSSER is designed to support reading and learning to read in a foreign language . There are four language pairs currently supported by GLOSSER : English-Bulgarian , English-Estonian , English-Hungarian and French-Dutch . The program is operational on UNIX and Windows '95 platforms , and has undergone a pilot user-study . A demonstration -LRB- in UNIX -RRB- for Applied Natural Language Processing emphasizes components put to novel technical uses in intelligent computer-assisted morphological analysis -LRB- ICALL -RRB- , including disambiguated morphological analysis and lemmatized indexing for an aligned bilingual corpus of word examples .

Predicate-is_designed_to_support.label: is designed to support
Predicate-is_designed_to_support.description: The predicate 'is designed to support' indicates that the subject has been intentionally created or structured to provide assistance, facilitation, or enhancement to the object. This connection implies a purposeful relationship where the subject's features, functions, or capabilities are aligned with the needs or goals represented by the object, thereby promoting effectiveness in achieving the specified outcomes.

Predicate-supports.label: supports
Predicate-supports.description: The predicate 'supports' indicates that the subject provides assistance, resources, or functionality to enable or facilitate the object. In this context, it implies that the subject has the capability or provision to work with, enhance, or promote the specified object, which can be a concept, activity, or set of items.

Predicate-includes.label: includes
Predicate-includes.description: The predicate 'includes' establishes a relationship where the subject is a broader category or collection that contains the object as a specific instance or component. It indicates that the object is part of the subject, highlighting a subset or specific example within a larger whole.

Predicate-is_operational_on.label: is operational on
Predicate-is_operational_on.description: The predicate 'is operational on' establishes a functional relationship between the subject and the object, indicating that the subject (typically a system, application, or program) is capable of running, functioning, or being utilized effectively within the environment or platform represented by the object. This implies compatibility and the ability to perform tasks or processes as intended when the subject is deployed in the context of the object.

Predicate-has_undergone.label: has undergone
Predicate-has_undergone.description: The predicate 'has undergone' indicates that the subject has experienced or completed a specific process, event, or transformation represented by the object. It implies a change or development that the subject has actively participated in, often suggesting a progression from one state to another as a result of the object.

Predicate-emphasizes.label: emphasizes
Predicate-emphasizes.description: The predicate 'emphasizes' indicates that the subject highlights, stresses, or brings attention to the object, suggesting that the object is of particular importance or relevance in the context of the subject.

Predicate-is_for.label: is for
Predicate-is_for.description: The predicate 'is for' establishes a relationship of purpose or intended use between the subject and the object. It indicates that the subject serves a specific function or is designed to fulfill a particular need represented by the object. In this context, the subject is associated with a goal or application that the object embodies.

Predicate-is_referred_to_as.label: is referred to as
Predicate-is_referred_to_as.description: The predicate 'is referred to as' establishes a relationship between a subject and an object by indicating that the subject is known or identified by the name or term represented by the object. This connection implies that the object serves as a label, title, or designation for the subject, often used in contexts where the subject may have multiple names or identifiers.

skos:broader.label: has a broader term
skos:broader.description: The predicate 'has a broader term' indicates a hierarchical relationship where the subject represents a specific instance or category that falls under a more general classification represented by the object. This relationship signifies that the subject is a subset or a specific example of the broader concept denoted by the object, thereby establishing a connection between the specific and the general.
